sen.j: 国衙領（こくがりょう）は、平安時代中期頃以降の公領を、荘園に対して呼ぶ歴史学用語。
sen.e: Kokugaryo is a history term referring to koryo (an Imperial demesne) after around the mid Heian period, differentiated from shoen (manor in medieval Japan).
Kokugaryo is a historical term referring to koryo (an Imperial demesne) after around the mid-Heian period, differentiated from shoen (manor in medieval Japan).
Kokugaryo is a historical term referring to koryo (an Imperial demesne) after around the mid-Heian period, differentiated from shoen (manor in medieval Japan).

sen.j: 国衙は令制国の役所の意味。
sen.e: "Kokuga" means the administrative institutions in ryoseikoku (provinces).
"Kokuga" means the administrative institutions in ryoseikoku (provinces).
"Kokuga" means the administrative institutions in ryoseikoku (provinces).

sen.j: 10世紀頃から、律令制で規定していた古代の戸籍制度・班田収授による租税制度がほぼ崩壊し、現地派遣の筆頭国司である受領へ租税納入を請け負わせる国司請負制へと移行し始めた。
sen.e: Since around 10th century, the tax system consisting of the ancient family registration system and handen shuju sei (a system of periodic reallocations of rice land) stipulated by the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code) had almost collapsed, gradually shifting into the kokushi ukeoi system, which made Zuryo (the head of the provincial governors, or Kokushi, who was sent to local provinces to administer) undertake tax collection in their provinces.

Since around the 10th century, the tax system consisting of the ancient family registration system and handen shuju sei (a system of periodic reallocations of rice land) stipulated by the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code) had almost collapsed, gradually shifting into the kokushi ukeoi system, which made Zuryo (the head of the provincial governors, or Kokushi, who was sent to local provinces to administer) undertake tax collection in their provinces.

Since around the 10th century, the tax system consisting of the ancient family registration system and handen shuju sei (a system of periodic reallocations of rice land) stipulated by the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code) had almost collapsed, gradually shifting into the kokushi ukeoi system, which made Zuryo (the head of Kokushi [provincial governors] who was sent to local provinces to administer) undertake tax collection in their provinces.

sen.j: これに伴い、受領の勢力下にある公領は、受領の私有財産のように扱われ始めた。
sen.e: Accordingly, koryo under the control of Zuryo began to be treated like their private assets.
Accordingly, koryo under the control of Zuryo began to be treated like their private assets.
Accordingly, koryo under the control of Zuryo began to be treated like their private assets.

sen.j: 受領は租税納入先の大寺社や摂関家のような上級貴族へ滞納が生じると、勤務評定である受領功過定（ずりょうこうかさだめ）を切り抜けるために、公領の一部の租税収納権を納入先の大寺社や摂関家に与えることが慣例になっていった。
sen.e: To deal with tax delinquencies designated to the main temples and shrines, and the high-ranked aristocracy including Sekkan-ke (the families which produced regents), it became customary for Zuryo to give away to those tax recipients the rights to collect taxes from parts of koryo, as an attempt to avoid poor evaluation with Zuryo koka sadame, their job performance reviews.

To deal with tax delinquencies designated to the main temples and shrines, and the high-ranked aristocracy including Sekkan-ke (the families which produced regents), it became customary for Zuryo to give away to those tax recipients the rights to collect taxes from parts of koryo, as an attempt to avoid poor evaluation with Zuryo koka sadame, their job performance reviews.

To deal with tax delinquencies designated to the main temples and shrines, and the high-ranked aristocracy including Sekkan-ke (the families which produced regents), it became customary for Zuryo to give away to those tax recipients the rights to collect taxes from parts of koryo, as an attempt to avoid poor evaluation with Zuryo koka sadame, their job performance reviews.

sen.j: こうしてなし崩し的に公領に虫食い状に発生した新立荘園、つまり国免荘（こくめんのしょう）は、次第に公領からの租税徴集を圧迫していった。
sen.e: In this way, newly-established shoen, or kokumen sho (a shoen allowed exemption from rice tax or other tributes), had been vermicularly spreading within koryo, strangling the tax collection from koryo.
sen.cmt: 原文の読みは「こくめんのしょう」となっていますが、登録用語では「kokumen sho」となっています。
sen.e: In this way, newly-established shoen, or kokumen sho (a shoen allowed exemption from rice tax or other tributes), had been vermicularly spreading within koryo, strangling the tax collection from koryo.

In this way, newly-established shoen, namely, kokumen no sho (a shoen allowed exemption from rice tax or other tributes), had been vermicularly spreading within koryo, strangling the tax collection from koryo.
sen.cmt: 原文表記に合わせました。

sen.j: 特に11世紀には内裏や大寺社の火災が多く、これらの再建を目的とした臨時課税が困難になる状況を来した。
sen.e: Especially in the 11th century, a number of fire disasters occurred in dairi (the Imperial Palace), main temples and shrines, and it was difficult to levy extraordinary taxes for their reconstruction.

Especially in the 11th century, a number of fire disasters occurred in dairi (the Imperial Palace), main temples and shrines, and it was difficult to levy extraordinary taxes for their reconstruction.

Especially in the 11th century, a number of fire disasters occurred in dairi (the Imperial Palace), main temples and shrines, and it was difficult to levy extraordinary taxes for their reconstruction.

sen.j: そのため、単なる既成事実であった国免荘にも課税（一国平均役）をするため、たびたび荘園整理令が出された。
sen.e: Therefore, Manor Regulation Acts were frequently ordered to levy taxes (Ikkoku heikinyaku, or taxes and labor uniformly imposed on shoen and kokugaryo in a province) even on kokumen sho, which was, after all, nothing more than an accomplished fact.

Therefore, Manor Regulation Acts were frequently ordered to levy taxes (Ikkoku heikinyaku, or taxes and labor uniformly imposed on shoen and kokugaryo in a province) even on kokumen sho, which was, after all, nothing more than an accomplished fact.

Therefore, Manor Regulation Acts were frequently ordered to levy taxes (Ikkoku heikinyaku [taxes and labor uniformly imposed on shoen and kokugaryo in a province]) even on kokumen no sho, which was, after all, nothing more than an accomplished fact.
sen.cmt: 前出用語に合わせました。

sen.j: これらの荘園整理令はある基準年以降の新立荘園を停止する一方、それ以前に発生していた国免荘を臨時課税の対象として正式に公認化するものでもあった。
sen.e: These Manor Regulation Acts prohibited establishment of new shoen after the designated base year, while legalizing these extraordinary taxes that were to be imposed on kokumen sho created prior to the base year.

These Manor Regulation Acts prohibited establishment of new shoen after the designated base year, while legalizing these extraordinary taxes that were to be imposed on kokumen sho created prior to the base year.

These Manor Regulation Acts prohibited establishment of new shoen after the designated base year, while legalizing these extraordinary taxes that were to be imposed on kokumen no sho created prior to the base year.
sen.cmt: 前出用語に合わせました。

sen.j: それまでの荘園は上級貴族や大寺社が独占的に租税収納権をもつ農地が公領の農地の中に散在しているに過ぎなかった。
sen.e: Before that, shoen were simply agricultural lands scattered in koryo, of which the tax collection rights were exclusively possessed by the high-ranked aristocracy and main temples and shrines.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Before that, shoen were simply agricultural lands scattered in koryo, of which the tax collection rights were exclusively possessed by the high-ranked aristocracy and main temples and shrines.
Before that, shoen were simply agricultural lands scattered in koryo, of which the tax collection rights were exclusively possessed by the high-ranked aristocracy, main temples and shrines.

sen.j: しかし、これらの荘園整理令に際し、公領と荘園を識別して一国平均役を課することを容易にするため、荘園を一つの領域に統合する措置が行われた。
sen.e: However, following these orders, the government took measures to integrate shoen into one domain as an attempt to differentiate between koryo and shoen, facilitating the levy of Ikkoku heikinyaku.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, following these orders, the government took measures to integrate shoen into one domain in an attempt to differentiate between koryo and shoen, facilitating the levy of Ikkoku heikinyaku.
However, following these orders, the government took measures to integrate shoen into one domain in an attempt to differentiate between koryo and shoen, facilitating the levy of Ikkoku heikinyaku.

sen.j: ここに上級貴族や大寺社が派遣した荘官が、行政や徴税を国家から依託される、統治領域としての荘園が成立した。
sen.e: Thus, shoen as a governing domain was established, where a shokan (an officer governing shoen dispatched by the senior aristocracy and main temples and shrines) was delegated authorities for local administrations and tax collections for the country.

Thus, shoen as a governing domain was established, where a shokan (an officer governing shoen dispatched by the senior aristocracy and main temples and shrines) was delegated authority for local administration and tax collection for the country.

Thus, shoen as a governing domain was established, where a shokan (an officer governing shoen dispatched by the senior aristocracy and main temples and shrines) was delegated authority for local administration and tax collection for the nation.

sen.j: こうしてそれまで各国の体制は、荘園も含めて一元的に受領の支配下にあったものが、荘官の支配する荘園と、受領の支配下にある公領が、大きく二分して土地・民衆支配をする形態に移行した。
sen.e: Eventually, the old provincial system, administered by zuryo collectively including shoen, was shifted into a new system, in which the control of lands and people was roughly divided into two on the basis of shoen (administered by shokan) and koryo (administered by zuryo).

Eventually, the old provincial system, administered by zuryo collectively including shoen, was shifted into a new system, in which the control of land and people was roughly divided into two on the basis of shoen (administered by shokan) and koryo (administered by zuryo).

Eventually, the old provincial system, administered by zuryo collectively including shoen, was shifted into a new system, in which the control of land and people was roughly divided into two on the basis of shoen (administered by shokan) and koryo (administered by zuryo).

sen.j: こうした体制下の公領を、受領の指揮下にある国衙の領地とみなして、国衙領と呼ぶ。
sen.e: Koryo under such a system is regarded as kokuga (provincial government offices) areas controlled by zuryo, and is called kokugaryo.
Koryo under such a system were regarded as kokuga (provincial government offices) areas controlled by zuryo, and were called kokugaryo.
Koryo under such a system were regarded as kokuga (provincial government offices) areas controlled by zuryo, and were called kokugaryo.

sen.j: また、歴史学者の網野善彦は、中世日本の社会が荘園と公領から構成されていることに注目して荘園公領制という概念を提唱した。
sen.e: Also, a historian Yoshihiko AMINO advocates a concept of shoen koryo sei (The System of Public Lands and Private Estates), focusing on the fact that the medieval Japanese society consisted of shoen and koryo.

Also, the historian Yoshihiko AMINO advocates a concept of shoen koryo sei (The System of Public Lands and Private Estates), focusing on the fact that medieval Japanese society consisted of shoen and koryo.

Also, the historian Yoshihiko AMINO advocates a concept of shoen koryo sei (The System of Public Lands and Private Estates), focusing on the fact that medieval Japanese society consisted of shoen and koryo.

sen.j: 国衙領は、鎌倉幕府が成立すると次第に守護・地頭の勢力の下に置かれるようになっていったが、室町時代にも残存した。
sen.e: After Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) was established, kokugaryo was gradually placed under the control of shugo (provincial constable) and jito (manager and lord of manor), but still remained in the Muromachi period.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: After the Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) was established, kokugaryo was gradually placed under the control of shugo(provincial constable) and jito (manager and lord of the manor), but still remained in the Muromachi period.

After the Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) was established, kokugaryo was gradually placed under the control of shugo (provincial constable) and jito (manager and lord of the manor), but still remained in the Muromachi period.
sen.cmt: スペース補足しました。

sen.j: その後、太閤検地により解体された。
sen.e: Afterwards, it was effectively dismantled by taiko kenchi (the cadastral surveys conducted by Hideyoshi).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Afterwards, it was effectively dismantled by taiko kenchi (the cadastral surveys conducted by Hideyoshi).
Afterwards, it was effectively dismantled by taiko kenchi (the cadastral surveys conducted by Hideyoshi).
